options.a: He ensures he always arrives at his destination in the shortest time
options.b: He uses his horn to warn others of his presence constantly
options.c: He treats others like partners, drives calmly and coolly and refrains from showing that he is superior

questions.explanation: A good driver is defined by a partnership attitude, calmness, and lack of arrogance/superiority.

questions.question_text: A car travelling behind is urging you along on a country road. The driver is obviously annoyed that you are travelling slightly slower than is permitted. How do you react?

options.a: You brake suddenly to warn him to back off
options.b: You let him overtake as soon as possible and refrain from paying him back for his jostling behaviour
options.c: You drive in the middle of the road to prevent dangerous overtaking

questions.explanation: Reacting with annoyance creates danger. The correct response is to let the aggressive driver pass safely.

questions.question_text: You are overtaking a queue of cars on the Highway. A car approaching very fast is pushing you. What do you do?

options.a: You tap your brakes to signal him to slow down
options.b: You maintain your speed and ignore him until you finish the whole queue
options.c: If there is a bigger space in the queue, you let the jostling driver pass

questions.explanation: If it is safe to move over (bigger space), allow the aggressive driver to pass to avoid a collision.

questions.question_text: A faster car overtakes you on a country road and cuts into your lane. How do you react?

options.a: You flash your lights to show your disapproval
options.b: You control your annoyance, remain cool and proceed as if you had not noticed this
options.c: You accelerate to close the gap

questions.explanation: Getting angry or retaliating increases the risk. The defensive approach is to remain cool and continue.

questions.question_text: Participating in road traffic requires caution at all times and consideration towards other road users. What does this mean for you?

options.a: You must reckon with improper conduct on the part of others
options.b: You must always insist on your right of way
options.c: You only need to follow the rules yourself

questions.explanation: You cannot assume others will drive perfectly. You must expect mistakes (improper conduct) from others.

questions.question_text: What should you understand by defensive driving?

options.b: Using the horn to communicate with other drivers
options.c: Not insisting on your rights and allowing for other people's mistakes

questions.explanation: Defensive driving is explicitly defined as not insisting on rights and making allowances for others' errors.

questions.question_text: What can cause unnecessary obstructions on the road?

options.b: Motor vehicles breaking down because they have run out of fuel
options.c: Waiting for a traffic light to turn green

questions.explanation: Running out of fuel is a preventable breakdown and causes an unnecessary obstruction to traffic.

questions.question_text: You have bought a vehicle which is registered. What must you do?

options.a: Submit proof of insurance to the registration authority
options.b: Wait for the previous owner to cancel their insurance
options.c: Drive it for 30 days before registering

questions.explanation: When buying a registered vehicle, you must submit proof of insurance coverage to the authority.

questions.question_text: What does 'power sound' in the car result in?

options.a: The driver stays awake better on long trips
options.c: Signals from other traffic – in particular sirens – are not heard

questions.explanation: Loud music ('power sound') drowns out acoustic warning signals like sirens and horns.

questions.question_text: What can cause a dangerous situation regarding brakes?

options.b: Brakes which engage heavily on one side
options.c: Brakes that have just been serviced

questions.explanation: Uneven braking (heavily on one side) causes the car to pull to the side, potentially leading to a loss of control.

questions.question_text: Which substances can impair fitness to drive in a similar way to alcohol?
questions.explanation: Certain medicines can have sedative effects or slow reaction times similar to alcohol intoxication.

questions.question_text: When overtaking, if the car being overtaken speeds up, what should the overtaking driver do?

options.a: Race the other car to get past
options.b: Force the other car to the side
options.c: Abort the overtake and drop back

questions.explanation: If a situation becomes dangerous while overtaking, the safe option is to back off (abort).

questions.question_text: The suspension of your motor vehicle has been lowered and an expert opinion must be obtained. When is this required?

options.c: When you decide to sell the vehicle

questions.explanation: Modifications like lowering suspension require immediate expert validation to ensure roadworthiness.

questions.question_text: Above which alcohol level in your blood can you expect your fitness to drive to be impaired?
questions.explanation: Impairment starts early. The threshold mentioned in the book is 0.3 per mille.

questions.question_text: What applies if you are driving on an open stretch of road at night and feel chilly or have heavy eyelids?

options.b: Drive faster to get home sooner
options.c: Interrupt your journey for an adequate break

questions.explanation: These are signs of fatigue. The only safe solution is to stop driving and take a break.
